still.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: used when saying that something continues to be the same as before, or has not happened yet
still.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: He still lives with his parents.
Do you still have Julie’s phone number?
I still haven’t finished painting the spare room.
still.translation[0].definitions[0].note: Still  comes before a main verb
Still can come before the verb ‘be’ when it is part of a contraction such as ‘isn’t’ or ‘wasn’t’
Still comes after the first auxiliary verb in positive sentences
The marks can still be seen
Still comes before the first auxiliary verb in negative sentences
I still can’t remember his name
We still  do not know exactly what happened
still.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: in spite of what has just been said or done
still.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: Clare didn’t do much work, but she still passed the exam.
still.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: We stood still and watched as the deer came closer.
Keep still while I tie your shoe.
the still waters of the lake
still.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: a still drink does not contain gas
still.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: a photograph of a scene from a film
still.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: a piece of equipment for making alcoholic drinks from grain or potatoes
still.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: to stop moving, or make something stop moving
still.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: The ground beneath them trembled, then stilled.
still.translation[3].definitions[1].defi: if a noise stills or is stilled, it stops
still.translation[3].definitions[1].exam: He stilled their protests with a wave of his hands.
still.translation[3].definitions[2].defi: if a doubt or fear is stilled, it becomes weaker or goes away
